Award.AwardTitle: New methods for treating electrostatics and adaptive partitioning in QM/MM simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Qiang Cui of the University of Wisconsin, Madison is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop accurate but efficient quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) methods for use in biological and complex chemical systems. The PI and his research group are pursuing effective electrostatic treatments for QM/MM simulations that employ finite sphere boundary conditions, thus helping to focus configurational sampling to the active site and making ab initio QM/MM simulations cost effective. They are developing a microscopic/mesoscopic model in which atoms within a spherical region are treated atomistically while the rest of the protein is represented by polarizable dipoles at the residue level; the bulk solvent is a Gaussian field, which is equivalent to a dielectric continuum in the static limit. One long term goal is to apply this new approach to identify molecular factors that dictate transition metal binding specificity in systems like metal chaperones and metal specific transcription factors. The methods are also being applied to chemical processes that explicitly involve many water molecules, either in bulk solution, the air/water interface or the interior of biomolecules.

The novel computational methods that the PI and his research group develop may be used to study a broad range of important problems in chemistry, biology, medicine and environmental science that are currently difficult or impossible to study. These theoretical/computational studies have the potential to reveal surprising mechanisms at the microscopic level that help explain macroscopic features of the systems. These methods are implemented in the popular simulation package CHARMM and are widely used by other scientific groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The general theme of the research is to develop novel and efficient molecular simulation methodologies and models for tackling challenging biological and chemical problems. More specifically, the research carried out can be classified into several general areas: (1) Treatment of both short-range and long-range electrostatics in ab initio and semi-empirical QM/MM calculations, so as to improve their general accuracy for highly charged/polar systems; (2) Application of the resulting QM/MM methods to analyze the active site features of metalloenzymes, including binding specificity and catalytic promiscuity; (3) Continuation in the development/calibration of DFTB3 and MM  models for biological applications, especially metalloenzymes that feature a significant degree of conformational flexibility; (4) Development of novel atomistic and coarse-grained models (BMW-MARTINI) for water and lipid molecules for pushing forward the accuracy and complexity of molecular simulations of complex interfaces. A significant number of publications have appeared in or been submitted to high quality journals such as J. Am. Chem. Soc, J. Chem. Theo. Comp. and J. Phys. Chem. The developed QM/MM methods have also been crucial to the investigation of several specific applications supported by other grants in the group. For  "image summaries" of researcha accomplishment, please visit our webpage:
http://www.chem.wisc.edu/~cui/gallery_2.html

 

The grant has been used to partially support several graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, some of whom also received separate fellowships to support their research activities. All supported individuals have publications. In terms of personnel career development, Dr. Z. Wu has successfully defended Ph.D. in Aug. 2012 and moved to UIUC as a postdoctoral fellow at the Center for the Physics of Living Cells, under the guidance of Prof. K. Schulten. Dr. Goyal has defended her Ph.D. in Aug. 2013 and moved to UIUC as a postdoctoral fellow in the Hammes-Schiffer lab. Other graduate students are also moving along with their research and studies; I expect Ms. Korkmaz and Lu to defend their Ph.D. in the next two years. For the postdoctoral fellows, who routinely participated postdoctoral seminar series established at UW-Madison Chemistry and also received mentoring advices regarding their careers, have all moved on. Dr. Zienau and Dr. Gaus have found successful industrial positions back in Germany, while Dr. Mori is moving back to Japan as an assistant professor at the prestigious Institute of Molecular Science.

The methods/models developed in this project have been implemented in the popular molecular simulation program CHARMM and therefore accessible to the general theoretical/computational (bio)chemistry community.
